Got a lift to Wolkersdorf with a sign "Brno" however during that hour, only about 10 Czech cars passed me. Also I didn't get too many interactions with the drivers.. but it's a nice spot to get from Vienna since the bus to the shopping mall is free - also this place is recommended by Hitchwiki👍🏼
Not so many cars, but if going somewhere, almost definitely to Graz

Raststation Kammern. OK to get to Graz, a lot of local traffic though. 
Has a coffee making room for truckies that you might be able to use!

You can get to the hitchspot for free with a bus from Innsbruck. For direction north There is a plenty of space to hitchhike on the road directly or you can ask on the gas station but there are mostly people from the oposite direction. The spot is good but you might still need to wait a bit to get lift to germany. If you are heading for A7 there is a better spot further up. About 10km further in Fernpass there is a gas station that is on the right side of the road where you can both ask and hitc
OMV gas station. Works with both directions Innsbruck and Füssen. Many cars in holiday times.

We stood with a sign ‘Graz’ but only roughly 70% of drivers noticed us and gave their gestures. There is a lot of cars driving directly to the highway direction Vienna and Graz. After roughly an hour or so we changed for a thumb only and a kind girl stopped for us.
Gave up after 5h, spend a night in Wienna and got carpool.
There is no pump its just restpoint for trucks could be good at morning i was here at 10am and gave it up after hour because of low traffic amd went 4km on previous pump

Last Gas Station before italy. many people buy their gaz there, because in italy it is more expensive. Good station for North and the south because it is easy to reach from both sides of the motorway.
Tried here and gave up quickly, cars taking the highway go on the left lane so they can't stop to take you.

Direction Innsbruck: we waited here quite some time - at least 30 min. Probably a carton saying 'Innsbruck' was not a good idea as most of the cars where going shorter distances. Got a lift to Landeck.
Had a sign to Maribor Zagreb, no chance, changed it to Graz and got there instantly, very nice people even took me to the next highway station
not so bad, not the most traffic. lots of trucks though, lots heading towards slovenia. got a ride quickly to wels.
Got a lift to Sofia in 1 hour with a Maribor sign. Asking around isn't effective because a lot of driver go to other direction
Tough one! It's not impossible, but there was just not much traffic - we waited for about 2,5 hours and found a car that took us all the way to München/Munich.
Took me 4h to catch ride north, quite some cars entered highway in direction Salzburg/Linz but not willing to pick me up from the exit of parking lot :( BTW S11 goes from graz to Zitoll (10 min walk)
trying to get out of the city towards italy, a friendly family picked me up and dropped me off at the innsbruck süd shell station :)) although most folks going through this area seem to be locals…
Viele Locals, Innsbruck, Innsbruck Land, was tendenziell eher schlecht is, aber guter Spot um auf die Autobahn zu kommen, mit etwas Glück

I took the tram from the main train station, tram 3 to Roserggerst, stopped there, then walked for about 10min. There is a little gas station there, but all the cars were driving into the city (still too central). Luckily from there, I got a ride to this gas station that is at the start of the highway. I waited about 20min, asking drivers. I got a lift a little before Kufstein (was going to Kufstein). Big Shopping mall nearby, cars stop (not plenty, but not few neither). Monday early afternoon.

2 or 3 guys, 2PM weekday

Very lot cars passing by, we tried Wien or Salzburg sign and didn't managed to get ride in two hours so we moved to Resselstraße bus stop. People also can't see the place where they can stop.
waited some 4 hours for a ride to Munich and then loosed hope. We went to Resselstrase bus stop and got a ride after 10 minutes to petrol station
very risky, although police ignored us. i recommend having a high-vis vest on

Right before the entrance of the tunnel there is a good spot for cars to stop. It's next to the SOS booth phone, we reached this place from the park above, (pass the small bridge in case you come from the city centre), the park is also a great spot to pitch a tent in case you wanna sleep here. :)
Great spot

Got dropped off here by a nice lady. Unfortunately I was headed for Munich, and previous advice from another hitcher the day before was that people going from Switzerland to Germany avoid using the autobahn since they have to buy a vignette. Instead, they cross the border through the towns and rejoin the autobahn there.

Might be OK if you're headed into Austria, though.

You can access this point by walking along the road that goes past the bus stop. There will be a bridge that crosses directly over the top, and you can see the entrance of the tunnel from the bridge.

We waited here for about 30 minutes in the middle of the day. There is a lot of traffic, but nowhere for cars to stop. We decided to move to a safer area.

We stood at this spot with a big sign. About 5 people stopped, but no one was going on the A10. After 3 hours we decided to leave. Be careful about this spot, the positive reviews are quite old and might not reflect this good it actually is.

After waiting for 30 min or so with a cardboard saying "A10", an Austrian grandma took us to the highway and dropped us on a big gas station in way to Villach, even she wasn't going that way!

Also, there is a big mall 200m northwards, with free wifi, free toilets and couchs! 
Useful when it's raining outside and you want to take a break.
Me and my friend tried this spot to get to Villach. Within 15 minutes an ambulance pulled over onto the wide lane on the right hand side and took us in that direction. Great spot, great memories!

It's quite a walk from the center, but a good spot to hitchhike South. I'd recommend standing on the road and not the P+R.
 If you get here at night there is a field to the left of this road that is good for wildcamping. Just walk a bit further South till you get to the Fürstenweg, enter it and to the right there is the field. Quite a nice view too.
I caused a car accident, because one driver didn’t pay attention to the road. The cops came and i had to wait 1h, until i could hitchhike again.

At the rastplaz, there is a road barrier. It can be opened, but when we were there, it was closed, so there was no option to hitchhike. We ended up sleeping at the place in the tent and it was working well.
We were 2 guys, got a hitch to a rastplatz towards Slovenia.

we stood by the side of the road and had a sign Slovenia, not an ideal place, but it worked very well for us, two of the best girls stopped, probably the best stop so far, although the plan was the mountains we went where they went and to the sea, 1.5. swimming in the sea? love it
The cars are fast so have a big sign

first waited by eni but no one stopped as cars coming from left were concerned with merging and cars already on were going quite fast. this spot proved better for slow cars (and shade!) and kind person refuelling went into eni and made me a sign for salzburg!
Good spot, a bit loud because of cars accelerating but visibility is great and drivers have plenty of space to stop
it is better to have a sigh, get a ride to salzburg in 20 minutes, good spot
Got a ride to Kufstein during the rain.
Literally waited less than a minute here at 9 AM on a Friday before I got a ride to Woergl
got ride towards Hungary, many traffic but hard to catch all the cars
For US perfect, we got a Ride to Budapest in 10 min but there is Not alot of Traffic.
Budapest. Sat there for a moment taking a break. A man smoking looked at my sign and offered me the ride. He was himself a hitchhiker long ago.

In August '15 we (2 females) were waiting 1h for a lift to Bratsislava. We must have been lucky. Also we met another female hitchhiker, who had spent on the gas station two nights trying to get to Slovakia. Bad place.
This place is not really that crowded. It's gorgeous, quiet and chill, but not too many cars to catch. On the lower-level parking you can find truck drivers going various directions.
A long wait for a long lift

Most of the cars were heading towards Austria or Switzerland. But luckily a local German grandma with her two grandchildren took me to next rest area on the highway, meanwhile explaining to the kids that she also used to do that and explained what trampen means to them etc. :’)
I got a lift just in one minute but the truck driver was from the same country as me. There arent so much cars here but you can find a truck easily and most of them go to München.

I was standing here with a MÜ sign for München, but it was really NO TRAFFIC, only few trucks stop here. On the other side (direction South) is cool because cars have to stop for the Austrian vignette, but for Germany they do not need... So do not expect cars here! :o Anyway, a guy pulled down quickly in the end so took me to München!

walk till the front of the toll station and wait there with a sign so the cars can see you early enough and can go onto the parking place!
the officers will even help you writing your sign or give you pens to write them!^^
Not a lot of cars going on at around 7 am - eventually found a ride towards Innsbruck

The direction signs shouldn't be a problem because as always the best way is to just ask people at the gas station or restaurant. For that it works reasonably well for direction Innsbruck, but of course it's difficult to filter cars going south/east from those going north.

I also waited for Ulm - 4 hours. In the end I should have taken Innsbruck, Salzburg or München, since I wanted to hitch to Berlin. Yes, I think the problem is the direction signs - it really confuses the drivers so they don't pay attention to you as much as they could somewhere else. My suggestion: ask them directly, if you end up here.

I would not recommend this spot for direction Germany. It is a confusing both direction gas station so very few people went to Germany and most of them in direction Munich. I waited for 4 hours as my next petrol station was just before Ulm.

this is a non stop gas station and a big parking for trucks. the best direction is Germany because the gas station is on this side but have connection on both ways. i waited 3 hours for a car to Wien. a lots of cars stops and ask me for shorter distance. i found a truck who took me all the way to Romania.
i went there from hohenems trains station walking. it is a little road not showing on the map going in the gas station.
waited for about one and a half hours before giving up - in theory the spot is good tho, good space to pull over

Waited there for some hours. Nobody stopped to pick me up. Had a sign saying A1 --> Linz, Wien. Spot should theoretically be alright as there is enough place for cars to stop. I ended up taking the train to Vienna.
I was with a pannel Linz and a driver took me in less than 30 min, but it was friday afternoon ans there was a festival in Linz the week end, so probably I was lucky
45 minutes - get a lift to linz, speed not fast because of traffic lights. make a sigh
A busstop on the main road from the center towards the highway. For direction East, Linz, Vienna and Graz
Asked at the charger - got a BYD ride to Vienna! this reststop works both ways!
Going south, I thought it would be bit more difficult, but it is possible! Got a Hungarian couple heading to Bled
Looong wait but I wanted to go past Villach and not to Italy so the cars who went my way were not that plentiful. Seems like half the cars drive to Graz direction and half to Villach.

Most of the traffic here goes to Klagenfurt or Villach. We were trying to reach Italy, but got no luck. All long distance travelers have got packed cars. The staff on the gas station were very unfriendly. Even got into trouble with the police for hitching from here. Eventually got a ride to Villach and tried reaching Italy from there with better results.

Wait in front of Burger King since most people go there and not at the petrol pump. I was a bit unlucky to get something for graz/vienna, but there were definitely many people going there, as well as towards slowenia.
